data.title: Sight Seeing
data.text: Wonderful and Educational. No cameras allowed. Self guided tour of how money goes from paper to US currency. Tour takes about 35 minutes. Movie takes about 15 minutes. Lots of walking. Younger kids may get bored after about 25 minutes. Teens and adults will stay engaged.  Watching millions of dollars right in front of you is exciting.

data.title: interesting but not much to see
data.text: Not making coins when I was there. Production line was small so disappointed there were not more and better displays. Good store for purchasing coin sets.

data.title: MONEY!!
data.text: very cool tour of the mint. love this place. well presented. the displays were nice and the stories told on the tour were interesting

data.title: Great tour.
data.text: I really enjoyed this tour and our tour guide, very knowledeable.  You have to make reservations on line, it is free.  Don't bring any thing but you ID and some money for the gift shop with you.  My husband even enjoyed it, he really didn't want to go.

data.title: In the Money
data.text: I never expected to be paid for our visit, but we were all given a penny for our thoughts!  The guide who brought us through always answered all of the question we had in our group and was certified on many of the machines on the production floor.  Please note you have to do your homework and reserve a tour time online a month in advance as they book up quickly.  We are wiser about how our money is made, enjoyed the presentation about the only theft at The Mint and certainly feel the Gift Shop is worth the trip.

data.title: Time well spent
data.text: The tour takes about 45 minutes and you will hear the history of the mint.  Also, you will hear about a gold theft that took place.  Our guide was excellent with children as well and kept us all entertained.  The tour is free and they even give you a penny blank and a real penny.  Don't plan on taking anything into the mint.  You can take your cell phone for pictures only.  You must go through security.  The process of signing up for the tour is a pain.  We were asked to go online, but the website was done.  We tried the phone system, but were unsuccessful with the options.  We just showed up at tour time and hoped for some no shows which occurred.  We were told it was up to security whether they would add you or not.  Highly recommended for both adults and children.

data.title: An good learning experience
data.text: Taking a tour of the mint is very interesting and you get to see some interesting coins. Their gift shop is also a great place to buy coins and different mint items.

data.title: Quie enjoyable for this history buff with a curious side!
data.text: Once scheduled and screened, my adult daughter and I enjoyed this tour.  We learned the history of the mint,coins,cool facts about historical characters. We saw coin being imprinted and packaged. We were treated to a sample blank and newly minted penny. We saw some gold bars and we shopped for gifts.  Worth the time to schedule a tour if you are in Denver.

data.title: Requires Reservation.  USMINT.GOV   Impressive Building.
data.text: We went to the mint and walk the outside because we did not get a reservation.  You can get one on usmint.gov on bottom in About section "Facilities & Tours".  they were all booked and we tried to get on wait list.  Better to get Reservation.  Gift shop was fun but would love to go back and see the inside of the mint.  There were several people surprised by this.  The answer from the man was since 911 a lot has changed.  Courtesy and helpfulness has not.

data.title: Interesting tour
data.text: Surprisingly interesting hour-long tour. Reservations online are booked 30 days in advance and you must have a reservation to attend, so plan ahead!

data.title: The Best Mint Tour_DvB
data.text:
Since you can't take photos within these or the Bureau of Printing and Engraving buildings, and these are museums with working industrial components, the tour quality is foremost determined by the guides. Our two guides were knowledgeable, humorous, and highly attentive to questions--even those unvoiced and only evidenced by a prolonged look at a display. Don't think the penny planchets handed out at the tour onset swayed me. These guys were great.

Of course you have to pass through security, so they advise arriving 30 minutes early. Parking is convenient, and I found an inexpensive garage two blocks away. Of note, timing is everything in Denver, it seems. If you plan to take the first tour of the morning, pay attention to the parking meters. You can pay in advance, but it is costly since the meters don't "run" until 8am or 9am... just be aware.

There are numerous displays and history, including Denver Mint-specific events. The security measures from a bygone era are especially interesting.

data.title: Unexpected great tour
data.text: I took this tour on a whim and was very impressed. Just the building itself would be worth the tour without the mint. It's like a palace inside. The mint tour was very informative and the tour person made it a fun and educational experiance.

data.title: Interesting
data.text: This was an informative and interesting tour.  You must pay for parking, and there is parking around the mint.  Look for the hourly lot by quiznos.  Need to arrive 30 minutes prior and the tour takes 45 min plus time for the gift shop.  The security is strict.  No bags/purses and belts/pocket items removed for screening.  Leave everything in your car.  Great tour for the price for sure.

data.title: Don't give up!
data.text:
I tried multiple times to get online to secure a reservation, and it was more difficult since I had a narrow window of time. Plan early and be flexible. 

Know that there is no photography allowed, and you will be searched as thoroughly as at any airport. The US Mint police however are a lot friendlier than the TSA agents. 

I found the various exhibits lining the tour route as interesting as watching the production process. This is a great family activity, but not real young kids.

data.title: Amazing glimpse into history!
data.text: This free tour was well worth it. The tour guide was very informative. Anyone who loves history will like this. I work for a financial institution and this was so insightful! Thank you!

data.title: Interesting and Educational
data.text:
As with other reviews, touring the Denver Mint is interesting, educational and well worth a visit.  The tour takes you through the mint’s history and the process of making coins.  The tour takes about 45 minutes.  The tour is also appropriate for pre-teens or older. There is a small museum to visit while waiting for the tour to begin.  The gift shop has items for both adults and children.

Reservations are required; walk-ins are not accepted. Visitors must be at the tour entrance 30 minutes in advance of the tour.  Late arrivals will not be admitted.  Prior to entry all visitors go through security screening. Large items such as purses, backpacks, packages, bags, strollers, etc., will not be permitted.  There is no locker storage available.   The mint does not permit the taking of pictures. Elevator access is available for those who with limited mobility.  

Paid parking is available on the street or in nearby parking lots.

data.title: A great, informative tour
data.text: The staff were quite friendly, even as they searched our bags and made us go through the metal detector.  Our tour guide gave us a lot of information, delivered with a lot of humor.  Even gave me great advice on a coin my Dad had.  He had a great voice that could be heard by the whole group.  We were, luckily a small group since we took the 8 a.m. tour.  It was not crowded, and they do monitor the number of people per tour.  Reservations are required.

data.title: A Neat Experience
data.text:
My wife, 8 yr. old daughter and I visited the U.S. Mint on Thursday, Oct. 13, 2016 for the 9:30 a.m. tour. I played the "stay up late" game exactly 30 days ahead of time in order to get reservations for our desired date & time and wound up getting reservations.

We arrived in downtown Denver a little early to make sure we found a place to park. We ended up parking in a parking deck one block from the Mint. As all should know, you must arrive at the mint 30 minutes prior to your tour time. You basically stand outside on the sidewalk and the U.S. Mint police explain to you that you will need to go thru a metal detector and that you cannot bring in backpacks, purses or take pictures inside.

After going thru the metal detectors and getting inside, our tour guide, Tom, gave everyone a new shiny penny and an unpressed penny as a souvenir. As I said, our tour guide was Tom and he was very professional and knowledgeable about the mint, its history and its processes. He was also very funny and personable and welcomed questions from everybody.

At all times, there were armed U.S. Mint police following the tour group and in every room we visited. Tom talked about the history of the mint, the whole process to make coins and even how Congress plays a large role in what coins will still be minted.

Most of the tour takes place on the 2nd floor and you get to view some of the processes of making coins from behind the glass. There is also a lot of neat memorabilia to look at too. It was very educational for everybody of all ages. Of course the gift shop has lots to cool stuff to buy, should you desire.

I highly recommend trying to get reservations for this tour and experiencing it.

data.title: Literally a One Cent Tour!
data.text: The sign up to get on this free tour is almost like getting a golden ticket to the Wonka Factory (but as a secure Federal facility I get why!).  If you can hang in there with their reservation system, it is really a neat tour. We did get to see coins being made the day we went. The tour guide was very informative and fun and the security folks try to make it painless (if you adhere to their instructions on the website you can zip on in). We were all given a new penny and a disc that would be used to stamp one (so they pay you to come!).

data.title: Book tickets way in advance
data.text: Just like most things it runs, the government manages to take a simple tour and act like it is a big inconvenience for them.  You have to make advance reservations and the reservation system is often offline or unavailable.  I love my country but loathe the system.  If this was a private company, the customer service alone would drive them into bankruptcy.
